columns.text: In this problem, we will solve for the cost of the company's debt based on the given bonds.

For the first bond, we fill first solve for the coupon payment value. To do this, we will use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Coupon payment}&=\text{Face value}\times \text{Coupon rate} \times (1/2)
\end{aligned}$$

For this, we are using $1/2$ since the payments are done semiannually so this means there are $2$ periods per year.

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Coupon payment}&=1000\times 0.05 \times (1/2)\\
&=\$25
\end{aligned}$$

Next, we need to solve for the present value. We can do this by simply multiplying the face value by the market price quote. In this bond, the price quote is $103.18\%$. This will give us a present value of:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value}&=1000 \times 1.0318\\
&=\$1031.8
\end{aligned}$$

We can now substitute the values we obtained to the formula in Step 2.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Yield to maturity}&=\dfrac{\$25+\frac{1000-1031.8}{5}}{\frac{1000+1031.8}{2}}\\[15 pt]
&=0.01835
\end{aligned}$$

However, this is still the pre-tax yield. Therefore, to get the after-tax yield, we will use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{After-tax yield}&=\text{Yield to maturity}\times (1-\text{Tax rate})\times 2
\end{aligned}$$

We will multiply the result by $2$ since there are $2$ periods per year since the payments are done semiannually.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{After-tax yield}&=0.01835 \times (1-0.22)\times 2\\
&=0.028626
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the after-tax yield or cost of debt of this bond is $0.028626$ or $2.8626\%$.

The same principle will be applied to the following bonds. For the second bond, we will get the coupon payment as:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Coupon payment}&=1000\times0.071 \times(1/2)\\
&=\$35.50
\end{aligned}$$

Next, we will solve for the present value using the price quote of $112.80\%$.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value}&=1000 \times 1.128\\
&=\$1128
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values above to the formula in Step 2, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Yield to maturity}&=\dfrac{\$35.50+\frac{1000-1128}{8}}{\frac{1000+1128}{2}}\\[15 pt]
&=0.018327
\end{aligned}$$

However, this is still the pre-tax yield. Therefore, to get the after-tax yield, we will use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{After-tax yield}&=\text{Yield to maturity}\times (1-\text{Tax rate})\times 2
\end{aligned}$$

We will multiply the result by $2$ since there are $2$ periods per year since the payments are done semiannually.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{After-tax yield}&=0.018327 \times (1-0.22)\times 2\\
&=0.02859
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the after-tax yield or cost of debt of this bond is $0.02859$ or $2.859\%$.

For the third bond, we will get the coupon payment as:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Coupon payment}&=1000\times 0.063 \times(1/2)\\
&=\$31.50
\end{aligned}$$

Next, we will solve for the present value using the price quote of $107.45\%$.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value}&=1000 \times 1.0745\\
&=\$1074.5
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values above to the formula in Step 2, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Yield to maturity}&=\dfrac{\$31.50+\frac{1000-1074.5}{15.5}}{\frac{1000+1074.5}{2}}\\[15 pt]
&=0.025735
\end{aligned}$$

However, this is still the pre-tax yield. Therefore, to get the after-tax yield, we will use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{After-tax yield}&=\text{Yield to maturity}\times (1-\text{Tax rate})\times 2
\end{aligned}$$

We will multiply the result by $2$ since there are $2$ periods per year since the payments are done semiannually.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{After-tax yield}&=0.025735 \times (1-0.22)\times 2\\
&=0.0401466
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the after-tax yield or cost of debt of this bond is $0.0401466$ or $4.01466\%$.

For the third bond, we will get the coupon payment as:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Coupon payment}&=1000\times 0.059 \times(1/2)\\
&=\$29.50
\end{aligned}$$

Next, we will solve for the present value using the price quote of $102.75\%$.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value}&=1000 \times 1.0275\\
&=\$1027.50
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values above to the formula in Step 2, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Yield to maturity}&=\dfrac{\$29.50+\frac{1000-1027.50}{25}}{\frac{1000+1027.50}{2}}\\[15 pt]
&=0.028015
\end{aligned}$$

However, this is still the pre-tax yield. Therefore, to get the after-tax yield, we will use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{After-tax yield}&=\text{Yield to maturity}\times (1-\text{Tax rate})\times 2
\end{aligned}$$

We will multiply the result by $2$ since there are $2$ periods per year since the payments are done semiannually.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{After-tax yield}&=0.028015 \times (1-0.22)\times 2\\
&=0.0437034
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the after-tax yield or cost of debt of this bond is $0.0437034$ or $4.37034\%$.

Now that we have the cost of debt for all bonds, we can now solve for the total cost of debt of the company by adding together all values for the cost of debt from each bond.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total cost of debt}&=2.8626\%+2.859\%+4.01466\%+4.37034\%\\[15 pt]
&=14.1066\%
\end{aligned}$$

The total cost of debt of the company is $14.1066\%$.
